BOTCHED ROBBERY BECOMES STANDOFF Sunkist Car Wash in Anaheim is evacuated and assistant manager locks men inside. ANAHEIM – A botched car-wash robbery turned into an all-day, armed standoff Sunday after employees of the Sunkist Car Wash locked three men inside the building and called police. One man surrendered after an hour, but the others remained holed up inside for more than seven hours and were still inside the building in the 2500 block of Lincoln Avenue late Sunday. About 8:30 p.m., police drove an armor-plated vehicle up to the building and tossed a cellular phone inside. "When you hear the telephone ringing, pick it up and talk to us," police said over a loudspeaker. "No one's going to get hurt." But the suspects refused to answer. The attempted robbery started about 3 p.m. after employees noticed the men eyeing an office containing the car wash's safe. First, they bought three Snapples and some cashews and hung around the waiting area, said cashier Jackie Contreras, 20. They played a golf video game and started watching her. "One of them was looking at me, and every transaction he would look," Contreras said. "I think he didn't know if he would rob me or the safe." Contreras said one of the suspects, described as a man with a shaved head in his early 20s, was standing near the door to the car wash office. She told him to move away from the office three times, but he didn't go anywhere. "He said, 'I understand,' but he didn't move," she said. Contreras said she also saw him signaling to someone inside the office, and then she noticed that the other two men had disappeared. She ran out of the car wash and got the attention of Assistant Manager Ramon Meza, who was standing in the detailing area. "She was running scared and told me we were getting robbed," Meza said. Meza, finding that the men had closed themselves into an office, quickly evacuated the business. Two employees and three customers were inside. Then he chained the outside door, normally a nighttime security precaution. Customers, realizing what was go on, left their cars and ran away. "I was getting out of my car and saw everyone running, so I just ran," said Luis Rubio. "I just wanted to take my baby and go." Rubio left his green Dodge Ram parked in the car-wash line and ran away with his 21/2-month-old son. Police said they were glad Meza locked the men inside the building. "It is unusual ," said Sgt. Rick Martinez. "And it was very fortunate for us." Snipers, SWAT members and the police K-9 unit surrounded the building and the Jiffy Lube next door. Duane Stout was about to finish paying for his oil change at the Jiffy Lube Station next door when he was told to leave by police. He left his blue Cadillac in the parking lot. Merry Christmas! Although the weather is not too convincing here in So. Cal (65), we are so excited to be celebrating our first Christmas together as husband and wife. We hear and see from our family and the news that the midwest has been pelted with snow. It's been an interesting few weeks, but nothing has been more adventurous than the past weekend. Where to start I'm not sure, other than to say that everything is ok. It all started last Saturday night. Brian was cleaning the bathroom (to surprise me while I was out) and accidentially knocked the curling iron off the counter and it turned on. Needless to say, when the phone rang, he didn't realize it and stepped on the curling iron burning the underside of his toes...OUCH! On the other end of the phone was none other than yours truly calling to say that I had been punched and mugged in the parking lot of a local WalMart. Yes, you read correctly. This guy came from between two cars, I looked up then he looked down and pretened to walk the other way. Suddenly he turned, punched me in the chest which knocked me off balance and then he grapped my purse off of my shoulder. This other guy drove up and he jumped in the "get away car" and were laughing histericially. I chased the car through the parking lot to get the license plate number. I was successful, except for one number. I stopped a car driving past and screamed for him to chase the car and get the plate # and direction they were headed. Luckily this guy was one of my guardian angels that night and did what I asked and returned. This young couple walked up to me b/c they heard me screaming for someone to call 911, they had and handed me their phone. I talked to the dispatcher and they the young woman walked me to my car. Praise God I had my keys in my hand, so the car was safe and sound. There was an awesome older hispanic man waiting by my car who saw me running and yelling. In the chaos of the moment I left my car door open and bags laying on the ground. So the police showed up and I talked to him, just as Brian showed up. We all went into the store and I went back and looked at the surveliance camera. It was really sickening watching my own demise on film, but the great part is that it is all on film! It was all premeditated, the camera showed that they had been watching me, then drove around the aisle dropped the theft off and then waited to pick him up. The police officer said that it will be charged as a felony since it was a theft and an assult. So he might spend a few years in jail! YIPPEE! After we were finished, we came home and spent the next 2 hours on the phone canceling my phone, credit cards, bank account and trying to remember what all I had in my purse. The only things that I think they really got of any value were my clie' and $20. Then our circuit breaker freaked out in our apartment and we had no power until Sunday. On Sunday afternoon Lori, my dear friend, stopped over to be a wonderful friend and give me a hug. While she was here we were in the kitchen where a candle was burning on the counter. She reached over it and suddenly her newly dry-cleaned sweater went up in flames. The chemicals from the dry-cleaning were burning and her sweater was ingulfed. We were screaming and hitting her with towels. After the flames were out we were amazed that her sweater wasn't even singed because the flame was burning on chemicals only and not her sweater. So she left, unharmed, and we had lunch and thought we'd load the dishwasher and relax before the college kids came over for our Christmas Party. After we stared the dishwasher, water started spuuing out from the bottom like some sort of funky fountain and flooding our kitchen floor. At this point we looked at each other, laughed, grabbed some towels and called maintenance "again." The great news was three fold 1.) I didn't get hurt, stabbed or shot by the mugger, 2.) For the 4-5 "tramatic" things that happened, we have 400-500 things to be thankful for and ways that we are blessed by God and 3.) We know that our marriage is stronger and they we can survive just about anything :) We are happy to report that our Christmas was less chaotic! We got up and had a Christmas breakfast of champions, cinnamon rolls! Then we open presents, the funny thing is that my sister got me a really cool purse for Christmas! Also, "santa" brought us NFL Blitz for our PS2...so Brian showed me how to play and I actually like it....a lot! Then we had lunch...I made Brian a Christmas "steak"....we didn't want to do turkey or ham...so we improvised! Sometimes, even thinking about yawning will make you yawn. And when the person next to you does it, forget about it -- you'll yawn, too. With all this talk about yawning, in fact, you've probably already yawned. "A yawn is an instinctive behavior: You don't have to learn to do it, and yawns are even present before birth," says Robert Provine, a professor of psychology and neuroscience at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. Is the myth that yawns are actually contagious true? "When one person in a group yawns, over half of the people in the group will yawn within five minutes, and the rest will at least be tempted to yawn," says Provine, who has been researching yawning for more than 20 years. "What is surprising is that virtually anything having to do with yawning triggers a contagious reaction." Provine explains that while yawning is highly contagious, so are other human behaviors, like laughter, and this reaction is actually very normal -- and ancient. "When you see someone else yawn, you don't think to yourself, 'Well, I'll yawn, too," says Provine. "It just happens -- it's instinctive, and it's a very primal aspect of human behavior that goes back to ancient herd mentality." -stolen from msnbc

...to quote and agree with Brian...."actually is a good movie"....it really it! I really think that anyone, of any age and any stage of love or lack there of would really enjoy this movie and walk away with something. It's funny, Brian and I were the youngest couple in the theatre. Interestingly enough there were a lot of singles there too, or at least people viewing it solo. I found this really ironic initially since it is a movie about love and being in love, right? Right, but wrong too. Granted the main preface of the film is love, but not the soley romantic, dating, sexual love. Given, that is the plot of a couple of the side story lines, but the main focus is about the different types of love. I.e. adult to adult, love of circumstances or chance, child to parent, ironic love, siblings, jealous love that is never actualized and sacrificial love. It's really interesting and intriguing all at the same time and I found myself routing for characters and situations that I wouldn't normally advocate for in reality and shying away from others that are a normal soap box for me. It's amazing what Hollywood can do in just two short hours to wisk you away to an alternate reality.....then with the flick of a light switch you're zapped back into the life and reality you brought into the theatre. Either way, I left the movie feeling great and filled with thought. enough of my diatribe....go see the movie, let me know what you think. Last night we went to the Chain Reaction to see the bands Limbeck and The Format, and they are so great live! The whole place was rockin' because they sold out which meant there were about 500 kids there. That makes for a packed show! We took our friends from college group, Mary, Melissa and Robbie. Robbie decided to go last minute so he and Brian dropped us off at to go get him a ticket and then they went to park the car. We were lucky too, because we bought one of the last three tickets they had. I think they had a blast. It was a great night. UNTIL.......we went out to get the car and go home and the car was GONE! Keep in mind it is now 11:30 pm My heart sunk and started beating so fast. I couldn't believe it. Brian kept saying, "Where's the car, oh my gosh it's gone, it's gone." I'm trying to process what is happening before my eyes or as the case was, what was NOT before my eyes (i.e. the car!) Now going on 12 midnight It turns out after a few phone calls we discovered that, although the security guy for Chain directed Brian to park there, it was an "authorized only - tow zone." You'd think that if the guy is directing cars there and there are already 10+ cars there that 1.) maybe they had made arrangements for extra parking, 2.) it was ok to park there. Well both of these were wrong. And the whole lot of cars got towed to an impound yard. I personally think the security guy was in ca-hoots with Tows-R-Russ, the place that now owned our car. So we are now stuck with two dilemas, no car and all of us stranded and how do we get back home. So Brian flagged down our friend Rory (to the rescue) who drives a mini cooper and he took me and the girls home to get our other car and drop them off to pick up their car to go home. Brian and Robbie got a ride from Rory's brother, which was a highly magical ride to say the least. (that's a whole different story) Anyway, finally all of our friends got their cars and were headed home. Now 12:30 am Now the second part of our adventure begins, we have to find this little tow place and plead and pay for the guy to let us have it back. We finally found it and the guy there was really scary. Almost like if you sneezed wrong he'd want to punch you. So after reviewing our options, we decided to purchase the $155 tow package. Included in this package is a towing fee of $90, plus vehicle storage @ $25 per day for two days and a $15 gate fee. (since it was towed at 10 pm and we picked it up at 12:30 am, that's two days - but I didn't want to chance arguing with this scary dude, if he says two days, well then it's two days) PLEASE NOTE MY SARCASIM!!! Now 1:30 am Bedtime. We finally get home and call it a day. So, today is a new day and luckily payday none-the-less so all in all it could have been much worse. I guess $155 isn't so bad compared to it being stolen. And also, I'm so glad we carpooled and didn't have our friends drive, that would have been three more cars at $155 each and I would have felt so bad for them. Ah, life's little treats. fun times. it makes for a good story, or so I hope.

So my boss got a pre-release coppy of the soon to be released movie "Saved". They sent it to him cos he's on some media think group...anyhoo.... I snagged it and watched it with Leah and Chad & Candy. If you haven't seen the trailer for it yet... urlLink check it out. It paints it in this really wacky light...that makes you kinda wanna watch it and also kinda stand against it. Well...here's the deal. It's an over the top, over spiritualized teen movie that paints Christians to look like complete A-holes. The movie makes the villian (the "non-Christian kids") to be the heroes in the end. The "super-spiritual-sqeeky-clean" kids turn out to be the jerks, the back stabbers, the ones "with the problem." It glorifies teen pregnancy, sexual promiscuity and "little sins". I will say this though... there were times where I thought "man...we are like that"....and it poked fun at the nice Christan subculture we sometimes live in. I found myself laughing at times and then wanting to turn the thing off at times too. It's a movie that could be a double edged sword. Kids/people that come into the film with a pre-concieved distain for Christianity will love it. It will just fuel thier fire. Kids that are super tight with Christ can possibly appreciate the movie for it's take on the Christian culture. But only for study and dialoge would this be good. And the kids on the edge...should steer clear of this movie. I'll probably encourage students to NOT see it...but I can't make em. My concern is that with the new found love of 'spiritual' entertainment...this could just be fuel for the other side of the fence. People who think that this movie is going to "bring Glory to God" are gonna be dissapointed. The glory ends up going to the enemy in this one.
